awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Bias Tracking and Reduction Methods for High-Dimensional Exploratory Visual Analysis and Selection
awd_abstract_narration:
Exploratory visualization and analysis of large and complex datasets is growing increasingly common across a range of domains. For example, online companies track users to learn about their products, computer security logs capture detailed traces of network activity, and health care systems capture detailed longitudinal records for their patients. In all of these fields, large and complex data repositories are being created with the goal supporting data-driven, evidence-based decision making. However, today's visualization tools -- a critical part of an analyst's toolbox -- are often overwhelmed when applied to high-dimensional datasets (i.e., datasets with large numbers of variables). Real-world datasets can often have many thousands of variables; a stark contrast to the much smaller number of dimensions supported by most visualizations. This gap in dimensionality puts the validity of any analysis at great risk of bias, potentially leading to serious, hidden errors. This research project will develop a new approach to high-dimensional exploratory visualization that will help detect and reduce selection bias and other problems with data interpretation during exploratory high-dimensional data visualization. The project's results, including open-source software, will be broadly applicable across domains. In addition, the project will be evaluated with users in a health outcomes research setting. This offers significant potential to improve health care around the world.
 
This project develops a set of Contextual Visualization Methods for exploratory data analysis which are designed to support the discovery of more robust and generalizable insights from high-dimensional data. These methods are built upon a recognition that the very summarization that makes many visual methods effective also inherently obscures aspects of a high-dimensional dataset that may be critical to accurate interpretation of a user's visual findings. More specifically, the subset of data (comprising both dimensions and records) that is actively accounted for within a visualization -- the data focus -- must be interpreted within the context of the many dimensions and data records that have been omitted or are not clearly represented within a visualization--the data context. The methods that this project develops, therefore, are designed to (1) explicitly model and analyze the data context, and (2) convey the relationship between the data focus and the context in order to better inform users about hidden problems such as confounding variables and selection bias. The primary technical contributions of the project include: (1) inline replication for visual validation; (2) baselined selection methods for high-dimensional visualization; (3) interactive rebalancing for representative visualization. In addition, open-source software will be developed and evaluated with real-world data and practitioners. The products of this research project -- including new methods, software products, and evaluation results -- will be disseminated through a project website (https://vaclab.web.unc.edu/contextual-visualization/).

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the design, development, and evaluation of new methods that can increase the reliability of using visualization-based tools to gain insights from complex data. The project resulted in three primary innovations. First, the project developed a method, inline replication, that provides a general approach to testing for repeatability in visualized findings. This helps reduce the chance that an analyst incorrectly identifies random variation as a meaningful signal. The second and third contributions focus on the risk of selection bias which emerges during exploratory data analysis. When selection bias grows, it can threaten the validity of any discoveries that are derived from the impacted data.  This project proposed two methods: (1) a method to both quantify and communicate selection bias as it emerges during exploratory visualization-based data analysis, and (2) a method to interactively correct for bias as an integrated part of the exploratory analysis. Lab-based studies measuring the efficacy of all three innovations show that they can be effective tools at improving user awareness about limitations of their data and thereby help reduce the chances of data analysts drawing insights that are not supported by their data. 

The project has resulted in a number of peer-reviewed scientific publications in the leading international venues including the most respected journals and conferences in the fields of visualization and visual analysis. These articles provide detailed descriptions of the new methods, how they were designed, and the results of evaluation studies which validate the approaches. In addition, the project has resulted in the creation of open-source software prototypes which provide a reference implementation of the proposed methods. In addition, the project’s research focus on selection bias quantification and minimization has helped spark a growing focus on issues related to bias (selection bias and bias in other forms) within the broader international visual analytics community, including researchers at other institutions who have built on the ideas generated by this project.  While these are complex problems that will require significant additional research to fully address, there is growing momentum in recognizing the challenges and beginning to work towards additional solutions. The findings from this project have triggered new lines of research include the idea of contextualizing visualizations not just with baseline data distributions (as done in this project to address issues of selection bias), but also the broader analytical context for a user's ongoing task. This has led to new ideas for analytical task and focus modeling as a way for interactive data analysis system to build and maintain a model of user's analytical interests and needs. This in turn can support various forms of intelligent user guidance, both to mitigate bias and to support other analytical needs.

Finally, impacts of this project extend well beyond the specific methodological innovations. Software developed through this project has been leveraged by a company in the pharmaceutical industry, has been used to analyze data related to the COVID-19 pandemic, and has been integrated into a pilot project to improve the quality of population health research activities at a large academic health system. Moreover, the project has impacted workforce development including research training for multiple predoctoral trainees, technical training for multiple Master’s degree level students, and undergraduate research experiences. The project team also included topics inspired by their research within training presentations shared with underrepresented-in-STEM populations during summer enrichment programs at UNC. Lastly, the challenges of data bias and related issues identified in this project have influenced the curriculum in a newly created UNC Graduate Certificate in Applied Data Science.
